Accordingly'"1 August the committee addressed memo-
. i t0 ihe parochial and municipal authorities for the requir-
d appropriations, and in September sent an agent into the
ountry to collect the money ; he obtained it from one parish
only St. Landry, but had assurances from the others, that
tiie wants would be made at the first meeting ofthe police
juries, unci the money forwarded immediately to the committee in New Orleans. Up to this time nothing further
has been heard from the parishes on the subject.
The memorials addressed to the municipal councils of
New Orleans were referred to committees in whose portfolios they slept nearly three months. Very recently the
respective councils appropriated their quotas towards the
surveys, and placed the same at the disposal ofthe Executive
Committee.
The delay ofthe councils in making the appropriations
arose, not from any opposition to the grants, but from
other causes.
In Summer, the councils meet but once a month, unless
upon extraordinary occasions ; and at those monthly meetings a quorum is often wanting, owing to absence of members from the city—and such is the amount and urgency of
regular business when the meetings arc held, that, matters of
this sort arc seldom reached before the time for adjournment.
The executive committee have determined not to wait
'"'' the action of the police juries. At their last meeting
'hey ordered the necessary surveys to be commenced immediately : and to obtain the required ready means
